slides.title: What is HTML?
slides.content:
**HTML** stands for **Hyper Text Markup Language**

Think of HTML as the **skeleton** of a website. Just like your skeleton gives structure to your body, HTML gives structure to web pages!

### Key Points:

- ğŸ“ HTML is the **standard markup language** for creating web pages
- ğŸ—ï¸ HTML **describes the structure** of a web page
- ğŸ§© HTML consists of a series of **elements**
- ğŸ·ï¸ HTML elements **label pieces of content** like "this is a heading", "this is a paragraph", "this is a link"
- ğŸŒ HTML elements tell the **browser how to display** the content

### Simple Analogy:

If a website were a house:

- **HTML** = The structure (walls, rooms, doors)
- **CSS** = The decoration (paint, furniture, style)
- **JavaScript** = The functionality (lights, plumbing, electricity)
slides.contentHtml:
HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language

Think of HTML as the skeleton of a website. Just like your skeleton gives structure to your body, HTML gives structure to web pages!

Key Points:

  • ğŸ“ HTML is the standard markup language for creating web pages
  • ğŸ—ï¸ HTML describes the structure of a web page
  • ğŸ§© HTML consists of a series of elements
  • ğŸ·ï¸ HTML elements label pieces of content like "this is a heading", "this is a paragraph", "this is a link"
  • ğŸŒ HTML elements tell the browser how to display the content

Simple Analogy:

If a website were a house:

  • HTML = The structure (walls, rooms, doors)
  • CSS = The decoration (paint, furniture, style)
  • JavaScript = The functionality (lights, plumbing, electricity)

slides.title: Why Learn HTML?
slides.content:
1. **Foundation of Web Development** - Every website uses HTML
2. **Easy to Learn** - You can create your first webpage in minutes!
3. **Universal** - Works on all browsers and devices
4. **Career Opportunities** - Essential skill for web developers
5. **Creative Freedom** - Build anything you can imagine!
slides.contentHtml:
1. Foundation of Web Development - Every website uses HTML
  2. Easy to Learn - You can create your first webpage in minutes!
  3. Universal - Works on all browsers and devices
  4. Career Opportunities - Essential skill for web developers
  5. Creative Freedom - Build anything you can imagine!

slides.title: HTML Basics
slides.content:
### What is an HTML Element? An HTML element is made up of: - **Start tag** - `` - **Content** - The text or other elements inside - **End tag** - `` ```html Content goes here... ``` ### Example: ```html

This is a heading

This is a paragraph

``` ### Important Notes: - âš ï¸ Some elements have **no content** (called empty elements) like `
` - they don't need a closing tag - ğŸ”¤ HTML is **NOT case sensitive** - `

` is the same as `

`, but **lowercase is recommended** - ğŸª† HTML elements can be **nested** (elements inside elements)
slides.contentHtml:
What is an HTML Element?

An HTML element is made up of:

  • Start tag - <tagname>
  • Content - The text or other elements inside
  • End tag - </tagname>
<tagname>Content goes here...</tagname>

Example:

<h1>This is a heading</h1>
<p>This is a paragraph</p>

Important Notes:

  • âš ï¸ Some elements have no content (called empty elements) like <br> - they don't need a closing tag
  • ğŸ”¤ HTML is NOT case sensitive - <P> is the same as <p>, but lowercase is recommended
  • ğŸª† HTML elements can be nested (elements inside elements)

codeBlocks.code:
This is a heading

This is a paragraph

slides.title: Your First HTML Document
slides.content:
Let's create a simple HTML page! ```html My First Web Page

Hello, World!

This is my first paragraph.

``` ### ğŸ“– Line-by-Line Explanation: 1. **``** - Declares that this is an HTML5 document - Must be the **first line** (before any HTML tags) - Helps browsers display the page correctly - Not case sensitive 2. **``** - The **root element** of the HTML page - Everything else goes inside this tag 3. **``** - Contains **meta information** about the page - Not visible to users - Includes things like title, links to CSS, etc. 4. **``** - Specifies the **title** shown in: - Browser's title bar - Browser tabs - Search engine results 5. **`<body>`** - Contains all the **visible content** - Everything users see goes here: - Headings, paragraphs, images, links, tables, lists, etc. 6. **`<h1>`** - Defines a **large heading** - Most important heading on the page 7. **`<p>`** - Defines a **paragraph** - Used for blocks of text
slides.contentHtml:
Let's create a simple HTML page!

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>My First Web Page</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello, World!</h1>
    <p>This is my first paragraph.</p>
  </body>
</html>

ğŸ“– Line-by-Line Explanation:

  1. <!DOCTYPE html>

    • Declares that this is an HTML5 document
    • Must be the first line (before any HTML tags)
    • Helps browsers display the page correctly
    • Not case sensitive

  2. <html>

    • The root element of the HTML page
    • Everything else goes inside this tag

  3. <head>

    • Contains meta information about the page
    • Not visible to users
    • Includes things like title, links to CSS, etc.

  4. <title>

    • Specifies the title shown in:
      • Browser's title bar
      • Browser tabs
      • Search engine results

  5. <body>

    • Contains all the visible content
    • Everything users see goes here:
      • Headings, paragraphs, images, links, tables, lists, etc.

  6. <h1>

    • Defines a large heading
    • Most important heading on the page

  7. <p>

    • Defines a paragraph
    • Used for blocks of text

codeBlocks.code:
Hello, World!

This is my first paragraph.

slides.title: HTML Elements Explained
slides.content:
### Nested Elements HTML elements can contain other elements. This is called **nesting**. ```html

My Website

Welcome to my website!

``` **Explanation:** - The `` element contains the `` element - The `` element contains `

` and `

` elements - This creates a **hierarchy** or **tree structure** ### Empty Elements Some elements don't have content and don't need a closing tag: ```html

``` ### Never Skip the End Tag! While some browsers might display pages correctly even with missing end tags, **always include them** for: - âœ… Better code quality - âœ… Avoiding unexpected errors - âœ… Following best practices ```html

This is a paragraph

This is another paragraph

This is a paragraph

This is another paragraph

```
slides.contentHtml:
Nested Elements

HTML elements can contain other elements. This is called nesting.

<html>
  <body>
    <h1>My Website</h1>
    <p>Welcome to my website!</p>
  </body>
</html>

Explanation:

  • The <html> element contains the <body> element
  • The <body> element contains <h1> and <p> elements
  • This creates a hierarchy or tree structure

Empty Elements

Some elements don't have content and don't need a closing tag:

<br />
<!-- Line break -->
<hr />
<!-- Horizontal rule/line -->
<img src="image.jpg" />
<!-- Image -->

Never Skip the End Tag!

While some browsers might display pages correctly even with missing end tags, always include them for:

  • âœ… Better code quality
  • âœ… Avoiding unexpected errors
  • âœ… Following best practices
<!-- âŒ Bad -->
<p>This is a paragraph</p>
<p>
  This is another paragraph

  <!-- âœ… Good -->
</p>

<p>This is a paragraph</p>
<p>This is another paragraph</p>

This is another paragraph

This is a paragraph

This is another paragraph

slides.title: ï¸ Common HTML Tags
slides.content:
### Headings (h1 to h6) HTML has **6 levels** of headings: ```html

Heading 1 - Most Important

Heading 2

Heading 3

Heading 4

Heading 5
Heading 6 - Least Important
``` **Tips:** - Use `

` for main page title (only **one** per page) - Use `

` to `

` for subheadings - Don't skip levels (don't jump from `

` to `

`) ### Paragraphs ```html

This is a paragraph of text.

This is another paragraph.

``` ### Links ```html Click here to visit Example.com ``` - `href` = the URL/destination - Text between tags = what users click on ### Images ```html ``` - `src` = path to the image file - `alt` = alternative text (for accessibility and if image doesn't load) ### Line Breaks ```html

This is line one.
This is line two.

``` ### Horizontal Line ```html

Section 1

Section 2

```
slides.contentHtml:
Headings (h1 to h6)

HTML has 6 levels of headings:

<h1>Heading 1 - Most Important</h1>
<h2>Heading 2</h2>
<h3>Heading 3</h3>
<h4>Heading 4</h4>
<h5>Heading 5</h5>
<h6>Heading 6 - Least Important</h6>

Tips:

  • Use <h1> for main page title (only one per page)
  • Use <h2> to <h6> for subheadings
  • Don't skip levels (don't jump from <h1> to <h4>)

Paragraphs

<p>This is a paragraph of text.</p>
<p>This is another paragraph.</p>

Links

<a href="https://www.example.com">Click here to visit Example.com</a>
  • href = the URL/destination
  • Text between tags = what users click on

Images

<img src="image.jpg" alt="Description of image" />
  • src = path to the image file
  • alt = alternative text (for accessibility and if image doesn't load)

Line Breaks

<p>This is line one.<br />This is line two.</p>

Horizontal Line

<p>Section 1</p>
<hr />
<p>Section 2</p>

codeBlocks.code:
This is a paragraph of text.

This is another paragraph.

This is line one.
This is line two.

slides.title: HTML Document Structure
slides.content:
Every HTML document follows this basic structure: ```html Page Title

Main Heading

Paragraph text...

``` ### Visual Representation: ``` â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ ... â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚

...

â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚

...

â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ ```
slides.contentHtml:
Every HTML document follows this basic structure:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
    <title>Page Title</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <!-- All visible content goes here -->
    <h1>Main Heading</h1>
    <p>Paragraph text...</p>
  </body>
</html>

slides.title: ï¸ Hands-On Practice
slides.content:
### Exercise 1: Create Your First Page Create a file called `index.html` and add: ```html About Me

About Me

Hi! My name is [Your Name].

I am learning HTML!

``` **To view it:** 1. Save the file 2. Double-click to open in a browser 3. See your first webpage! ğŸ‰ ### Exercise 2: Add More Elements Enhance your page with: ```html About Me

About Me

Introduction

Hi! My name is [Your Name].

I am learning HTML!

My Interests

I enjoy:

  • Coding
  • Reading
  • Gaming

Contact

Email me at: your@email.com

© 2024 [Your Name]. All rights reserved.

``` ### Exercise 3: Understanding the Structure Try this experiment: 1. Remove the `` - what happens? 2. Remove a closing `

` tag - what happens? 3. Change `

` to `

` - what's different? 4. Add multiple `
` tags - what do you see?
slides.contentHtml:
Exercise 1: Create Your First Page

Create a file called index.html and add:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>About Me</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>About Me</h1>
    <p>Hi! My name is [Your Name].</p>
    <p>I am learning HTML!</p>
  </body>
</html>

To view it:

  1. Save the file
  2. Double-click to open in a browser
  3. See your first webpage! ğŸ‰

Exercise 2: Add More Elements

Enhance your page with:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>About Me</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>About Me</h1>

    <h2>Introduction</h2>
    <p>Hi! My name is [Your Name].</p>
    <p>I am learning HTML!</p>

    <h2>My Interests</h2>
    <p>I enjoy:</p>
    <ul>
      <li>Coding</li>
      <li>Reading</li>
      <li>Gaming</li>
    </ul>

    <h2>Contact</h2>
    <p>Email me at: <a href="mailto:your@email.com">your@email.com</a></p>

    <hr />
    <p><small>© 2024 [Your Name]. All rights reserved.</small></p>
  </body>
</html>

Exercise 3: Understanding the Structure

Try this experiment:

  1. Remove the <!DOCTYPE html> - what happens?
  2. Remove a closing </p> tag - what happens?
  3. Change <h1> to <h6> - what's different?
  4. Add multiple <br> tags - what do you see?

Contact

Email me at: your@email.com

© 2024 [Your Name]. All rights reserved.

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.content:
âœ… **HTML is the foundation** of all websites  
âœ… **HTML uses tags** to structure content  
âœ… **Every HTML document** needs `<!DOCTYPE html>`, `<html>`, `<head>`, and `<body>`  
âœ… **Elements can be nested** inside each other  
âœ… **Always close your tags** (except empty elements)  
âœ… **Use semantic tags** - they describe the content's meaning
slides.contentHtml:
âœ… HTML is the foundation of all websites
âœ… HTML uses tags to structure content
âœ… Every HTML document needs <!DOCTYPE html>, <html>, <head>, and <body>
âœ… Elements can be nested inside each other
âœ… Always close your tags (except empty elements)
âœ… Use semantic tags - they describe the content's meaning

slides.title: Next Steps
slides.content:
Now that you understand HTML basics, you can:

1. **Learn more HTML tags** - forms, tables, lists, etc.
2. **Add CSS** - make your pages beautiful!
3. **Learn JavaScript** - make your pages interactive!
4. **Build projects** - practice makes perfect!
slides.contentHtml:
Now that you understand HTML basics, you can:

  1. Learn more HTML tags - forms, tables, lists, etc.
  2. Add CSS - make your pages beautiful!
  3. Learn JavaScript - make your pages interactive!
  4. Build projects - practice makes perfect!

slides.contentHtml:
• W3Schools HTML Tutorial
  • MDN Web Docs
  • HTML Validator

slides.title: Quick Reference
slides.content:
### Basic Template ```html Title ``` ### Common Tags Cheat Sheet | Tag | Purpose | Example | | ---------------- | --------------- | ------------------------------- | | `

` to `

` | Headings | `

Title

` | | `

` | Paragraph | `

Text

` | | `` | Link | `Link` | | `` | Image | `` | | `
` | Line break | `Line 1
Line 2` | | `
` | Horizontal line | `
` | | `` | Bold text | `Bold` | | `` | Italic text | `Italic` | | `
    ` | Unordered list | `
    • Item
    ` | | `
      ` | Ordered list | `
      1. Item
      ` |
slides.contentHtml:
Basic Template

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Title</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <!-- Content here -->
  </body>
</html>

Common Tags Cheat Sheet

Tag Purpose Example
<h1> to <h6> Headings <h1>Title</h1>
<p> Paragraph <p>Text</p>
<a> Link <a href="url">Link</a>
<img> Image <img src="pic.jpg" alt="Pic">
<br> Line break Line 1<br>Line 2
<hr> Horizontal line <hr>
<strong> Bold text <strong>Bold</strong>
<em> Italic text <em>Italic</em>
<ul> Unordered list <ul><li>Item</li></ul>
<ol> Ordered list <ol><li>Item</li></ol>

slides.title: Untitled Slide
slides.content:
**Happy Coding! ğŸ‰**

Remember: Everyone starts as a beginner. The key is to **practice, experiment, and have fun!**

Remember: Everyone starts as a beginner. The key is to practice, experiment, and have fun!
